text_summary: The brain is the central organ of the nervous system enclosed within the cranium. It comprises the cerebrum, cerebellum, and brainstem and is the primary target for neuroimaging studies.
imaging_characteristics: Gray matter (35-45 HU on CT), white matter (20-30 HU), CSF (0-10 HU). MRI: cortical gray matter hyperintense on T2, white matter hyperintense on T1.
common_pathologies: Stroke, hemorrhage, tumor, demyelination, atrophy, hydrocephalus

text_summary: The cerebral hemispheres are the largest portion of the brain, divided by the longitudinal fissure. Each hemisphere contains frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
imaging_characteristics: Sulcal-gyral pattern visible on CT and MRI. Cortical ribbon 2-4mm thick. Best evaluated on coronal FLAIR and T1 sequences.
common_pathologies: Infarction, hemorrhage, cortical contusion, glioma, metastasis, encephalitis

text_summary: The cerebral ventricles are a system of four interconnected CSF-filled cavities including the lateral ventricles, third ventricle, and fourth ventricle. Ventricular size is a key neuroimaging metric.
imaging_characteristics: CSF-filled spaces appearing hypodense on CT (0-10 HU), hyperintense on T2 MRI, hypointense on T1 MRI, suppressed on FLAIR.
common_pathologies: Hydrocephalus, intraventricular hemorrhage, ependymoma, choroid plexus papilloma, colloid cyst

text_summary: The left lung consists of two lobes (upper and lower) separated by the oblique fissure. It is slightly smaller than the right lung due to the cardiac impression.
imaging_characteristics: Air-filled parenchyma with -700 to -900 HU on CT. Pulmonary vasculature visible. Fissure identified as thin linear opacity. Volume ~2.5L.
common_pathologies: Pneumonia, lung cancer, pneumothorax, atelectasis, emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis

text_summary: The right lung has three lobes (upper, middle, and lower) separated by the horizontal and oblique fissures. It receives slightly more ventilation than the left lung.
imaging_characteristics: Three lobes visible on CT with well-defined fissures. Air-filled parenchyma at -700 to -900 HU. Right middle lobe commonly affected by atelectasis.
common_pathologies: Pneumonia, lung cancer, pneumothorax, atelectasis, bronchiectasis, aspiration

text_summary: The heart is a four-chambered muscular organ in the mediastinum responsible for systemic and pulmonary circulation. Cardiac imaging evaluates morphology, function, and perfusion.
imaging_characteristics: Myocardium 40-60 HU on non-contrast CT, enhances to 100-150 HU. MRI cine SSFP shows bright blood, dark myocardium. Coronary calcium visible as high-density foci.
common_pathologies: Coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, valvular disease, pericardial effusion, myocardial infarction

text_summary: The liver is the largest solid abdominal organ, located in the right upper quadrant. It has a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and portal vein.
imaging_characteristics: Homogeneous parenchyma 50-70 HU on CT. Enhances in arterial and portal venous phases. Hepatic steatosis causes decreased attenuation. MRI: isointense on T1, slightly hyperintense on T2.
common_pathologies: Hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases, hemangioma, cirrhosis, steatosis, abscess

text_summary: The kidneys are paired retroperitoneal organs that filter blood and produce urine. Each kidney measures approximately 10-12cm in length with distinct cortex and medulla.
imaging_characteristics: Cortex 30-50 HU pre-contrast, enhances to 130-200 HU. Corticomedullary and nephrographic phases distinct on CT. MRI: cortex hyperintense on T2, medulla less so.
common_pathologies: Renal cell carcinoma, cysts, stones, hydronephrosis, pyelonephritis, angiomyolipoma

text_summary: The spleen is a lymphoid organ in the left upper quadrant posterior to the stomach. It is the most commonly injured solid organ in blunt abdominal trauma.
imaging_characteristics: Homogeneous 40-60 HU on CT. Characteristic zebra-stripe enhancement pattern in arterial phase. MRI: hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2. Normal size < 13cm.
common_pathologies: Splenomegaly, splenic laceration, infarction, lymphoma, cyst, abscess

text_summary: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal gland with exocrine (digestive enzyme) and endocrine (insulin) functions. It has head, neck, body, and tail segments.
imaging_characteristics: Homogeneous 40-50 HU on CT. Best seen in pancreatic phase (40-50s post-contrast). Fatty replacement common with age. MRI: hyperintense on T1 fat-sat due to protein content.
common_pathologies: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma, pancreatitis, IPMN, neuroendocrine tumor, cystic neoplasm

text_summary: The aorta is the main systemic artery originating from the left ventricle, comprising ascending aorta, aortic arch, and descending thoracic and abdominal segments.
imaging_characteristics: Dense contrast opacification on CTA (200-400 HU). Wall calcification common in elderly. Normal ascending aorta diameter < 4cm. MRI: flow void on spin echo, bright on SSFP.
common_pathologies: Aortic aneurysm, dissection, intramural hematoma, atherosclerosis, coarctation

text_summary: The pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs. The main pulmonary artery bifurcates into right and left branches.
imaging_characteristics: Best evaluated on CTPA with contrast opacification. Main PA diameter > 29mm suggests pulmonary hypertension. Filling defects indicate pulmonary embolism.
common_pathologies: Pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, PA aneurysm, tumor encasement, chronic thromboembolic disease

text_summary: The cervical spine comprises seven vertebrae (C1-C7) supporting the head and protecting the cervical spinal cord. C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) have unique morphology.
imaging_characteristics: Cortical bone bright on CT (>400 HU). Vertebral body alignment assessed on sagittal. MRI: cord signal, disc hydration (T2 bright), ligamentous integrity.
common_pathologies: Fracture, disc herniation, stenosis, spondylosis, cord contusion, metastasis

text_summary: The thoracic spine comprises twelve vertebrae (T1-T12) with articulations for the ribs. It provides structural support and protects the thoracic spinal cord.
imaging_characteristics: Vertebral body height and alignment on sagittal images. Kyphotic curvature normal. MRI evaluates cord, disc, and marrow signal.
common_pathologies: Compression fracture, disc herniation, metastasis, Scheuermann disease, scoliosis

text_summary: The lumbar spine comprises five vertebrae (L1-L5) bearing the majority of axial load. It is the most common site of degenerative disc disease and herniation.
imaging_characteristics: Large vertebral bodies. MRI: sagittal T1/T2 for disc assessment, axial T2 for stenosis. CT myelography alternative. Facet joints and foramina best on axial.
common_pathologies: Disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis, compression fracture, degenerative disc disease

text_summary: The ribs are twelve paired curved bones forming the thoracic cage. They protect the heart and lungs and are commonly injured in chest trauma.
imaging_characteristics: Cortical bone on CT. Fractures may be occult on CXR but visible on CT. 3D volume rendering helpful for multiple fractures. Bone scintigraphy for stress fractures.
common_pathologies: Fracture, metastasis, fibrous dysplasia, enchondroma, osteomyelitis

text_summary: The mediastinum is the central compartment of the thorax between the lungs, containing the heart, great vessels, trachea, esophagus, and lymph nodes.
imaging_characteristics: Best evaluated on CT with contrast. Divided into anterior, middle, and posterior compartments. Fat, soft tissue, and vascular structures identifiable by density and enhancement.
common_pathologies: Lymphadenopathy, thymoma, lymphoma, germ cell tumor, aortic aneurysm, esophageal mass

text_summary: The pleura consists of visceral and parietal layers lining the lungs and chest wall respectively, with a potential pleural space between them.
imaging_characteristics: Normally not visible on imaging. Pleural thickening or effusion makes it apparent. Fluid in dependent portions. CT best for loculated effusions and pleural masses.
common_pathologies: Pleural effusion, pneumothorax, mesothelioma, pleural thickening, empyema

text_summary: The thyroid gland is a butterfly-shaped endocrine organ in the anterior neck that produces thyroid hormones. Nodules are extremely common and usually benign.
imaging_characteristics: Hyperattenuating on CT (100-120 HU due to iodine content). Ultrasound primary modality for nodule assessment. MRI useful for substernal extension.
common_pathologies: Thyroid nodule, goiter, thyroid cancer, thyroiditis, Graves disease

text_summary: The breast is composed of glandular tissue, adipose tissue, and fibrous stroma. Mammographic density varies widely and affects cancer detection sensitivity.
imaging_characteristics: Mammography: dense tissue appears white, fatty tissue dark. BI-RADS density categories A-D. MRI with contrast for high-risk screening and extent of disease.
common_pathologies: Breast cancer, fibroadenoma, cyst, calcifications, ductal carcinoma in situ, phyllodes tumor
